abstract.p: Microbial communities in the deep biosphere underpin global biogeochemical cycles, yet their evolutionary responses to extensive anthropogenic disturbances remain unclear. Uranium in-situ leaching (ISL), a dominant mining strategy, creates persistent radiochemical and redox gradients in aquifers, providing a unique system for studying subsurface microbial evolution. Here, by exploiting metagenomics and metatranscriptomics in examining microbial responses through various mining stages at neutral U ISL sites, we show that geochemical changes accompany significant alterations in microbial community composition, oxidative stress, biogeochemical cycling, and overexpression of DNA repair genes. Comparative metagenomics and metatranscriptomics revealed elevated non-synonymous to synonymous polymorphism ratios and altered nucleotide diversity correlated with radiochemical gradients, underscoring the influence of environmental stress in promoting microbial evolution. Our results demonstrate that neutral ISL drives adaptive genetic and functional diversification of subsurface microbiomes and extend core microbial evolutionary frameworks to anthropogenically modified subsurface environments, redefining the deep biosphere as a dynamic, responsive system.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Microbial consortia in the deep subsurface adapted to nutrient-scarce, anoxic environments1–4 mediate critical biogeochemical processes and help maintain groundwater quality5–8. However, anthropogenic stresses arising from mining, groundwater extraction, and energy production are perturbing these fragile environments at increasing rates9. Recent studies have shown that environmental stresses, including heavy metal contamination and altered pH, affect groundwater microbial communities10,11. Mining operations are particularly disruptive, as they rapidly subject pristine subsurface ecosystems to heavy metals, radioactive contaminants, altered redox conditions, and electrochemical gradients9. Notably, a recent study in the abyssal seafloor showed that deep-sea mining can cause biological disruptions persisting for decades12, underscoring the need to assess long-term impacts of subsurface resource extraction on microbiomes. Although distinct from the deep subsurface examined here, this finding underscores how resource extraction can impose long-lasting impacts on microbial communities in Earth’s hidden biomes.

In-situ leaching (ISL), a widely used uranium (U) mining technique, is based on injecting oxidizing agents into aquifers to mobilize U by oxidizing insoluble U(IV) to soluble U(VI). In addition to fundamentally altering groundwater chemistry13, this activity imposes profound chemical and radiological stress on microbial communities that have evolved over eons under stable, reducing conditions. Whereas the environmental consequences of ISL are well documented mostly via 16S rRNA gene analysis11,14–16, the evolutionary responses of microbial communities to these stressors remain poorly understood. Indeed, while mining-driven alterations to groundwater chemistry are expected to disrupt the microbial community structure, functional potential, and genetic diversity17–20, the question remains as to whether anthropogenic stress can drive microbial evolution in deep aquifers.

To this end, we implement innovative metagenomic and metatranscriptomic strategies to examine microbial community dynamics and evolutionary adaptations at a neutral-pH ISL area (CO2 + O2 ISL). It involved sampling aquifers spanning mining spanning pre-mining, active mining, and post-mining phases. Leveraging this rare sampling opportunity to study microbial adaptation as a response to mining and geochemical changes, we show that U exposure and radiochemical stress drive the restructuring of microbial communities, oxidative stress response and DNA repair, and alterations in genetic diversity. Elevated pN/pS ratios (the ratio of the rates of non-synonymous (pN) and synonymous (pS) polymorphism) and shifts in nucleotide diversity implicate mining-induced environmental gradients in significantly altering microbial evolutionary processes. Our findings yield new insights into how deep subsurface microbiomes structurally and evolutionally adapt to anthropogenic stress, bearing implications for global biogeochemical cycles, ecosystem resilience, and bioremediation strategies. As mining operations continue to intersect with fragile groundwater ecosystems, understanding the evolutionary implications to subsurface microbial communities will be of critical importance to predicting the long-term impacts of resource extraction from Earth’s deep biosphere. The findings of this investigation underscore the consequences of uranium ISL on the evolution of subsurface life, offering a novel framework for appraising microbial resilience and adaptation in mining-impacted deep subsurface ecosystems.

sec.title: Geochemical and radiological alterations during and following Uranium ISL
sec.p: Neutral pH uranium in-situ leaching (U ISL) commences while the aquifer is in its natural state (pre-mining phase), proceeds through the injection of leaching solutions (mining phase), and concludes with natural restoration efforts upon cessation of mining activities (post-mining phase; Fig. 1). We monitored the all phases of neutral-pH ISL, having collected 80 groundwater samples from four distinct mining sites (S1, S2, S3a, and S3b; Figs. 1b-c). These sites underwent neutral ISL for varying durations, creating a unique time-resolved dataset with considerable variation in their redox conditions, from neutral-reducing pre-mining (BG, baseline groundwater) to weakly acid-oxidizing during mining (MT, mining groundwater), and back to neutral-reducing post-mining (PMI, PMIS, and PMS, representing initial, intermediate, and stable post-mining phases; Figs. 1b–c).

In the neutral-reducing pre-mining phase, low concentrations of total dissolved uranium (TU; 0.44 ± 0.31 mg/L; Fig. 2b) were detected, indicative of ongoing U mineralization under reducing conditions. This environment was rich in electron donors, including dissolved organic carbon (DOC, 5.26 ± 3.51 mg/L), Fe(II) (0.85 ± 1.11 mg/L), ammonium (0.73 ± 0.70 mg/L), and sulfide (0.92 ± 1.18 mg/L) (Fig. 2 and Table S1). These sources likely fuelled the reduction of Fe(III), and sulfate, and enhanced the reductive immobilization of U in the aquifer.

During the oxidizing mining phase, the injection of CO2 + O2 mobilized U from ore deposits. Total dissolved uranium (TU) concentrations increased rapidly after in-situ leaching activities commenced (from MT0.25 to MT1), peaking after roughly four years (MT4), followed by a gradual decline thereafter (from MT5 to MT20) (Fig. 2b). The oxidation of U(IV) to U(VI) and the subsequent formation of soluble uranyl-carbonate complexes were the primary drivers of TU increase21,22, as evidenced by strong positive correlations between TU and bicarbonate concentrations (Spearman correlation, ρ = 0.43, n = 80, p < 0.0001) (Fig. S1). Significant increases in sulfate and nitrate were also observed during this phase, both positively correlated with TU (sulfate-TU, ρ = 0.65, n = 80, p < 0.0001; nitrate-TU, ρ = 0.69, n = 80, p < 0.0001) (Fig. S1), likely resulting from the oxidation of pyrite and ammonium, respectively21,22.

Upon ISL decommissioning, the groundwater redox potential (Eh) decreased significantly, likely due to the degradation of dissolved organic matter (DOM; particularly protein-like and humic substances23). This transition from oxic to anoxic conditions was further evidenced by a decline in TU, sulfate, and sulfate/Cl ratios declined, while Fe(II) concentrations increased. This suggested the microbial reduction of Fe(III) and sulfate, alongside the reductive natural attenuation of U(VI)23. TU concentrations did not return to pre-mining levels (Fig. 2), however, indicative of incomplete restoration of the aquifers’ original geochemical conditions.

As U and its decay products emit α and β radiation, changes in groundwater radioactivity can serve as indicators of U mobilization and contamination. Monitoring α and β activity therefore during mining operations, with elevated gross (α + β) values indicating radiogenic element mobilization, while declining levels after mining suggest the efficacy of natural attenuation processes in limiting further U migration. Here, gross (α + β) radiation levels increased significantly after mining activities commenced, but decreased following ISL decommissioning (Figs. 2c-e). These changes in radioactivity correlated strongly with TU concentrations (ρ = 0.24, n = 80, p < 0.0001; Fig. S1), underscoring the coupling between uranium mobilization and radiogenic activity during mining and attenuation phases.

sec.title: Thousands of metagenome-assembled genomes reveal microbiome changes and enhanced co-occurence resulting from in-situ mining activity
sec.p: Sixty groundwater samples representative of the pre-mining, mining, and post-mining conditions across more than 20 years of neutral-pH ISL were metagenomically sequenced (Fig. 1). Nonpareil25 analysis indicated that sequencing coverage, exceeding 75%, was of sufficient depth to accurately reflect the aquifer microbiome diversity (Fig. S2). To assess both bacterial and archaeal diversity, we focused on analyzing the ribosomal protein S3 (rpS3) gene26, a single-copy, universally conserved marker that provides high phylogenetic resolution for both bacteria and archaea, yielding 12,972 sequences that clustered (at 99% similarity) into 6,487 representative sequences. Taxonomic assignments based on the Genome Taxonomy Database (GTDB, r220) grouped 6,431 rpS3 sequences into 215 distinct phyla (21 archaeal, 194 bacterial; Fig. S3). Groundwater microbial community composition and alpha diversity, based on rpS3 gene profiles, were strongly influenced by geochemical gradients, particularly uranium concentration and radiochemical activity, with higher diversity and distinct community structures observed under elevated stress conditions (Figs. S4 and S5).

Through bioinformatic analysis, we identified 4,036 medium-quality metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs; completeness > 50%, contamination < 10%)27, from which 2,255 strain-cluster representative MAGs (strain-cluster rMAGs) were obtained via dereplicating at strain-level (99% ANI). These included 1,165 high-quality and 1,090 medium-quality strain-cluster rMAGs bearing a median completeness of 96.5%, contamination of 1.7%, and N50 of 50,891 (Fig. 3 and Table S2). These MAGs represented 64 of the 215 phyla detected and accounted for roughly 35% of the total phylum-level diversity detected via rpS3, thus providing a robust representation of the predominant microbial communities at Qianjiadian sites (Figs. S3, S6, and S7). The phyla comprising the remaining 6.9% of rpS3-based abundance were likely absent from the strain-cluster rMAGs because their low abundance hindered successful genome reconstruction (Fig. 2a).

Neutral-pH ISL significantly altered microbial diversity in the mining aquifer, as revealed by rpS3 gene profiles. Microbial diversity showed strong positive correlations with uranium concentration and radioactivity, with prolonged neutral-pH ISL(S3a_MT04 and S3a_MT05) associated with increased Shannon and Invsimpson indices (ANOVA, p < 0.05; Tukey HSD post-hoc test; Fig. S4). Microbial community composition shifted markedly across the ISL chronosequence, as shown by non-metric multidimensional scaling (NMDS) and sample-to-sample correlation analyses of strain-cluster rMAGs (Figs. 3e, 4a–d). Communities from pre-mining, mining, and post-mining stages formed distinct clusters, with ANOSIM indicating significant separation between stages (R = 0.72, p < 0.001; Fig. 4d), reflecting divergent community trajectories during and after ISL. Network analysis of relative abundances of strain-cluster rMAGs revealed positive correlations, accounting for 90.4% of all edges, defined as significant correlations between taxa, dominating microbial interactions (Fig. 4e). Four distinct modules were identified, with microbial compositions of Module 1 remaining stable throughout neutral-pH ISL, indicative of a core microbial community. By contrast, the microbial compositions of Modules 2 and 4 were more prevalent during the early stages of neutral-pH ISL (indicative of adaptation), while that of Module 3 associated primarily with post-mining (indicative of recovery and/or attenuation; Figs. 4f-i). These results highlight the significant shifts in microbial community structure, diversity, and ecological interactions imposed by neutral-pH ISL. The observed tendency towards positive interactions emphasizes the dynamic and evolving nature of subsurface microbiomes in response to acute environmental stress, although such co-occurrence may arise from a variety of ecological processes.

sec.title: Neutral-pH ISL impacts gene expression linked to DNA repair, oxidative stress, and biogeochemical cycling
sec.p: To investigate microbial metabolic adaptations in response to long-term neutral-pH ISL, we analyzed gene expression from 45 metatranscriptomic samples representative of pre-mining, mining, and post-mining conditions over a 20-year period. By integrating gene expression profiles with our suite of 2,255 de-replicated and functionally annotated strain-cluster rMAGs, we identified widespread overexpression (coverage increase at least 2-fold) of genes involved in DNA repair, oxidative stress responses, and biogeochemical cycling (Fig. S8-S14). A corresponding Spearman correlation heatmap revealed coherent expression patterns and their associations with key environmental drivers (Fig. 5a). Principal coordinate analysis (PCoA) identified key environmental variables, such as Fe(II), gross alpha radioactivity, and bicarbonate, as major drivers of gene expression during different neutral-pH ISL phases (Figs. 5b-d). Specifically, Fe(II), gross radioactivity (alpha and beta) and redox potential (Eh) associated with the overexpression of DNA repair genes (Fig. 5b), while Fe(II) and nitrate correlated with oxidative stress response gene expression (Fig. 5c). Changes in bicarbonate, Fe(II), Eh and pH affected genes involved in biogeochemical cycling (Fig. 5d). These findings indicate that both geochemical and radiochemical gradients jointly shape microbial metabolic responses during neutral-pH ISL.

Microbial populations at the 20-year ISL site exhibited extensive DNA damage responses, as shown by the overexpression of genes involved in homologous recombination, nucleotide excision repair, and mismatch repair pathways (Figs. 5a and 5e), reflecting adaptation to the persistently oxidative, metal-rich, and radiological conditions maintained during prolonged neutral-pH ISL. The abundance of a key overexpressed gene (recA) involved in homologous DNA repair28, was moderately correlated with gross (α + β) radioactivity (ρ = 0.52, n = 32, p < 0.05) (Fig. 5e). Similarly, U concentrations showed moderate associations with increased expression of soxY, a gene involved in the sulfur oxidation (Sox) system (ρ = 0.44, n = 26, p < 0.05), as well as with genes linked to ammonium oxidation, including amoA (ρ = 0.43, n = 8, p < 0.05) and amoB (ρ = 0.43, n = 10, p < 0.05) (Fig. 5e). Functional genes associated with iron, nitrogen, and sulfur redox transformations, processes that regulate electron flow and thereby influence U speciation and mobility, were widely distributed across 100 strain-cluster rMAGs. These included Cyc2 cluster genes mediating Fe(II) oxidation in Gallionella spp. (potentially affecting U(IV) oxidation), amoAB genes for ammonia oxidation in Nitrosarchaeum spp., and soxY genes for sulfur oxidation in Pseudomonadota spp. (Fig. 5e). This functional consistency, potentially underpinned by redundancy and convergent adaptation, points to environmental filtering as a key mechanism structuring microbial communities under sustained geochemical stress29–33.

sec.title: Uranium ISL-induced stress drives genetic diversification in subsurface aquifers
sec.p: Genetic diversity and evolutionary pressures were assessed for species-cluster rMAGs by calculating non-synonymous to synonymous polymorphism (pN/pS) ratios, which indicate the balance between neutral variation and adaptive selection, and by appraising nucleotide diversity via PCoA to capture overall genetic variation among populations. Only genes with greater than 5× coverage in both metagenomic and metatranscriptomic datasets were included, and analyses focused on dereplicated species-cluster rMAGs (95% ANI) containing more than three clustered members (1,733 species-cluster rMAGs). This ensured robust comparisons across neutral-pH ISL phases. PCoA revealed that, based on metagenomic and metatranscriptomic data, both nucleotide diversity (Fig. 6g, i) and pN/pS ratios (Fig. 6h, j) were influenced by groundwater geochemistry. Nucleotide diversity was positively associated with bicarbonate, gross (α + β) radioactivity, sulfate, DOC, and Eh, and negatively with sulfide and pH (bioenv correlation analysis R2, 0.27). Similar patterns were observed for pN/pS ratios, although with slightly reduced explanatory strength (bioenv correlation analysis R2, 0.31). These results indicate that U concentrations, redox conditions, and radiochemical stressors all contribute to alterations in microbiome genetic diversity and evolutionary trajectory during and following neutral-pH ISL.

Across metagenomic datasets, no significant differences were observed in pN/pS ratios or nucleotide diversity during neutral-pH ISL. By contrast, metatranscriptomic data revealed elevated pN/pS ratios at both mining-impacted and post-mining sites, with median values increasing from 0.585 in S3a_BG to 0.608 in S3a_MT05, and from 0.380 in S3b_BG to 0.503 in S3b_MT15 and 0.491 in S3b_PMS, respectively (Figs. 6b, c). Notably, non-synonymous SNPs were detected in 481 genes that were transcriptionally overexpressed and functionally linked to oxidative stress responses, DNA repair, and cycling of carbon, nitrogen, sulfur, and iron (Fig. S15b), suggesting that positive selection preferentially targeted actively transcribed genes under stress. Notably, pN/pS ratios exceeding 1 were predominantly found in the metatranscriptomic datasets, with 7 species-cluster rMAGs in BG, 47 species-cluster rMAGs in MT, and 5 species-cluster rMAGs in PM, while only 5 species-cluster rMAGs (four in MT and one in PM) exhibited pN/pS ratios exceeding 1 in both metagenomic and metatranscriptomic datasets (Fig. S16). These results suggest that elevated genetic variation during ISL is linked to transcriptionally active taxa responding to combined radiochemical and geochemical perturbations, including oxidative stress and the influx of new substrates such as oxygen from leaching solutions, rather than a simple genome-wide increase in mutation rates. This framework also explains why post-mining communities, despite residual radioactivity, exhibit reduced diversity as redox conditions stabilize and substrate inputs diminish. The fact that no significant changes were detected in the early mining phase (Fig. 6a) suggests that the extent/duration of mining plays a major role in the process of natural selection. However, it should be noted that only one sample (BG6 in S2 site) from the background aquifer was available during the early mining phase, which may limit the conclusions drawn from these data and underscores the need for further sampling to better understand evolutionary dynamics at this stage.

Metatranscriptomic data revealed distinct evolutionary responses to neutral-pH ISL across mining stages, marked by dynamic shifts in nucleotide diversity and species-level selection. During the mid-mining phase (MT in S3a site), nucleotide diversity significantly increased relative to both background and other mining stages (Fig. 6d–f), coinciding with peak uranium and radioactivity levels. This suggests that sustained radiochemical and oxidative stress promoted elevated genetic variation, potentially by enabling the persistence of diverse genotypes capable of tolerating extreme conditions. By contrast, the early and late mining phases exhibited reduced nucleotide diversity, likely reflecting genetic bottlenecks driven by acute oxidative perturbations and the selective loss of more vulnerable populations. Notably, post-mining samples also showed diminished nucleotide diversity, despite the fact that both TU and radioactivity levels remained elevated. These findings suggest that both the intensity and duration of oxidative and radiochemical stress play a major role in shaping genetic diversity in mining-impacted aquifers.

To better understand the genomic basis of adaptive responses, we identified 31 species-cluster rMAGs that exhibited consistent increases in nucleotide diversity from background (BG) to mining-impacted (MT) conditions (Figs. 7a-b). These rMAGs spanned diverse taxonomic groups, such as Bacteroidales, Gallionella, Hyphomonas, and Kuenenia, suggesting that the response to mining-related stress was phylogenetically widespread (Fig. 7c). Gene-level analysis showed that elevated nucleotide diversity was spread across many genes within each species-cluster rMAG, rather than being limited to a few specific regions, suggesting widespread mutational pressure under long-term environmental stress (Fig. 7c). Functional categorization of highly variable genomic regions showed enrichment in genes associated with information processing, regulatory networks, and cellular signaling, functions that are likely essential for coping with radiochemical and oxidative stress. Notably, the majority of these diversity increases were detected in metatranscriptomic data, reinforcing the interpretation that selection is preferentially acting on actively expressed genes. These patterns suggest that under prolonged mining stress, a subset of microbial populations, those that remain transcriptionally active, exhibit elevated genetic diversity, potentially as a bet-hedging strategy to enhance adaptive flexibility. However, the absence of a community-wide increase in nucleotide diversity suggests that evolutionary responses to ISL are concentrated in metabolically active, redox-cycling taxa (e.g., iron-oxidizing Gallionella and nitrogen-oxidizing Nitrosarchaeum), while many other lineages remain genetically stable or enter dormancy under extreme stress. This indicates that anthropogenic disturbance does not uniformly accelerate microbial evolution, but instead drives targeted adaptation in functional groups central to biogeochemical cycling. This decoupling between metagenomic and metatranscriptomic signals highlights that evolutionary responses are concentrated within metabolically active fractions of the community, rather than reflecting broad community-wide genomic shifts. Notably, the functional categories enriched among highly variable regions, such as information processing, regulatory systems, and cellular signaling, further suggest that selection is acting on genes directly relevant to stress resilience. Taken together, these findings reveal elevated diversity among transcriptionally active strains in mining-impacted aquifers, underscoring how long-term ISL introduces radiochemical stress and geochemical perturbations, including altered redox conditions and new electron donors and acceptors, that collectively shape the active microbial fraction. While the overall genomic potential of the community may remain conserved, sustained environmental disturbance appears to activate and favor adaptive subpopulations, with responses driven not only by stress tolerance but also by shifts in substrate availability and redox gradients.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The global resurgence of nuclear energy has renewed interest in U ISL, a minimally invasive yet chemically intensive extraction method poised to dominate future uranium supply chains34,35. Given its operational efficiency and limited surface disturbance, U ISL is expected to remain a dominant extraction method where geological conditions permit in the near future13. While the geochemical and biodiversity impacts of U ISL are well documented13,17–21,23,36–38, its evolutionary consequences for subsurface microbiomes remain underexplored. Here, we present metagenomic and metatranscriptomic evidence that neutral-pH U ISL exerts sustained selective pressure on microbial populations, driving in situ evolution in deep aquifers.

Neutral-pH ISL introduces persistent redox and geochemical gradients to subsurface ecosystems by injecting oxidants into anoxic strata, mobilizing uranium, radionuclides, and heavy metals. By examining a neutral-pH ISL area with aquifers having undergone different time periods of leaching (up to 20-years), we reveal that these sustained geochemical disturbances go beyond restructuring of microbial community composition and alter transcriptional activity, along with an increased genetic diversity illuminating long-term ecological and evolutionary consequences for deep biosphere microbiomes. These transformations are shaped by sustained selection pressures imposed by neutral-pH ISL, including oxidative stress, redox-active metal toxicity, and low-dose radiation, stressors known to destabilize cellular systems and promote adaptive traits linked to stress tolerance, DNA repair, and redox regulation39–41. Correspondingly, we detected increased taxonomic diversity and ecological modularity in neutral-pH ISL-impacted aquifers, signatures consistent with stress-induced diversification11,42–46. Temporal succession patterns revealed dynamic microbial responses, with oxidative stress-tolerant taxa dominating early neutral-pH ISL stages and anaerobic fermenters and metal reducers emerging post-mining, reflecting adaptation to evolving geochemical conditions.

Crucially, these ecological transitions were accompanied by molecular signatures of adaptation. Genes associated with oxidative damage, heavy metal toxicity, and radiation exposure were broadly overexpressed throughout all neutral-pH ISL stages (Figs. S8-S14), suggesting a constitutive stress response. Yet, some strains showed a substantial change in nucleotide diversification along with neutral U ISL enabling the conclusion that repair mechanisms may have been insufficient to counteract accumulated genomic damage. Consequently, elevated nucleotide diversity, particularly in mid-mining metatranscriptomes, supports the hypothesis that mutational input exceeded repair capacity, consistent with models of stress-induced mutagenesis47–50. This model posits that environmentally triggered DNA damage, coupled with error-prone repair, contributes to increased mutation rates. While DNA repair pathways buffer deleterious mutations, they may also limit adaptive potential by constraining the fixation of beneficial variants51,52. In our study, elevated nucleotide diversity together with transcriptional activation of DNA repair and oxidative stress–response genes indicates that adaptive evolution is concentrated in metabolically active redox-cycling taxa rather than across the whole community. This resolves the modest community-wide transcriptional changes yet strong gene-level positive selection signals (Fig. S15b), highlighting that long-term ISL creates evolutionary hotspots where radiochemical stress and altered substrate availability jointly promote adaptation in key biogeochemical taxa.

These patterns are further supported by pN/pS ratios exceeding one, a canonical signal of positive selection, detected predominantly in metatranscriptomes (47 species-cluster rMAGs in mid-mining and 5 in post-mining), with only limited overlap to respective metagenomes. Notably, the species-cluster rMAGs exhibiting elevated nucleotide diversity spanned diverse taxa and showed widespread gene-level variation in information processing and regulatory functions, underscoring that selection acts primarily on transcriptionally active populations. This layered response, genome-wide mutation accumulation coupled with transcription-linked selection, highlights the dual role of environmental stress in both generating genetic variability and filtering for functional adaptation, consistent with eco-evolutionary rescue models53–55, wherein microbial populations rebound from stress-induced bottlenecks through the acquisition and retention of adaptive mutations.

Our study provides rare empirical evidence that stress-induced mutagenesis and transcription-linked selection operate in natural deep subsurface microbiomes over decadal timescales. Although such mechanisms are well characterized in laboratory systems56–62 and diverse surface environments47,63–66, their manifestation in oligotrophic, energy-limited subsurface ecosystems67–70 has remained largely speculative due to assumptions of metabolic quiescence and evolutionary stasis71–74. Our findings challenge this paradigm, demonstrating that chronic anthropogenic stress in engineered aquifers can generate sustained mutational input and facilitate directional selection. The convergence of elevated nucleotide diversity, DNA repair activation, and positive selection in expressed genes reveals a coordinated evolutionary response to long-term environmental disturbance. These observations extend core theoretical frameworks, including stress-induced mutagenesis and eco-evolutionary rescue, from controlled systems to complex, anthropogenically modified subsurface environments, redefining the deep biosphere as a dynamic, evolutionarily responsive system.

sec.title: Study area, sampling strategy, and sample collection
sec.p: The study area located in the Qianjiadian U ore deposit within the QJD sag of the Kailu Depression in the southwestern Songliao Basin, northeast China, represents a typical sandstone-hosted uranium system75. The stratigraphy comprises the Qingshankou (K2qn), Yaojia (K2y), and Nenjiang (K2n) formations, overlain by Neoproterozoic and Quaternary alluvial deposits. The uranium mineralization is primarily hosted in the K2y Formation, which consists of red, yellow, gray, and mineralized gray sandstones, with widespread carbonate cementation (dolomite, siderite, ankerite, and calcite). Pitchblende and coffinite are the dominant uranium minerals, while Fe-Ti oxides, natural organic matter (NOM), clay minerals, and pyrite serve as additional uranium hosts36,76–78. Groundwater flow follows a southwest-to-northeast trajectory within a confined Cretaceous sandstone aquifer (~298 m depth, 35 m thickness), with permeability coefficients averaging 0.145 m/day21. The aquifer is hydraulically isolated by a low-permeability mudstone-dominated aquitard, with limited connectivity to adjacent hydrogeological units.

The Qianjiadian uranium deposit has been a key site for advancing in-situ recovery (ISR) technology in China, serving as the first large-scale demonstration of CO2 + O2 leaching in a deep, low-permeability sandstone-hosted system. During the neutral-pH ISL process, the mixed reagent of dissolved O2 (oxidant) and CO2 (complexing agent) was injected into the ore-bearing aquifer, and subsequently, U-containing groundwater was pumped out and U was retrieved using ion exchange resins21,79. The effluent from the reverse osmosis system was reused as a leaching solution after being mixed with CO2 and O2 to maintain carbonate buffering and oxidizing conditions80. The orebody, located within confined sandstone aquifers at depths ranging from 220 to 460 m, presents complex hydrogeological conditions that influence solute transport, aquifer reactivity, and microbial community dynamics. The unique geological and hydrogeochemical setting of the Qianjiadian deposit, combined with its prolonged history of in situ leaching (ISR) operations, establishes it as a natural laboratory for investigating subsurface fluid-rock-microbe interactions, uranium mobilization processes, and the long-term geochemical and microbial responses to neutral-pH ISL as well as post-mining restoration.

To investigate the hydrogeochemical and microbial responses to neutral-pH ISL mining, groundwater samples were collected from the Qianjiadian (QJD) sandstone-hosted uranium deposit during two field campaigns in October-November 2021 and August–October 2022 (Figure 1). A total of 80 groundwater samples were obtained from sites representing different stages of neutral-pH ISL, spanning ore-bearing aquifers at depths of 220–460 m. Sampling locations encompassed neutral-pH ISL sites spanning multiple operational durations: 0.25 years (MT0.25, 8 samples), 1 year (MT1, 3 samples), 4 years (MT4, 6 samples), 5 years (MT5, 7 samples), 6 years (MT6, 6 samples), 15 years (MT15, 6 samples), and 20 years (MT20, 4 samples). Post-mining phases were sampled under distinct redox conditions, including iron-reducing (PMI, 4 samples), mixed iron- and sulfate-reducing (PMIS, 2 samples), and sulfate-reducing (PMS, 3 samples) conditions. Background aquifer samples (BG, 19 total) were collected across the chronosequence, including non-mining areas (5 samples), early-stage sites (MT0.25 and MT1, 1 sample), mid-stage sites (MT4 and MT5, 5 samples), and late-stage/post-mining sites (MT15, MT20, and PM, 8 samples). Background wells were present at all sites and sampled concurrently with mining and post-mining wells, providing site-specific baseline controls. Detailed hydrogeochemical data for MT20, MT4, MT5, PMI, PMIS, PMS, and BGPM are reported in our previous studies21–23,36.

Prior to sample collection using a deep groundwater sampler (Geosub 2, Geotech, USA), monitoring and post-mining wells were pumped for at least 20 minutes until water temperature, electrical conductivity (EC), and oxidation-reduction potential (ORP) stabilized. Groundwater was then pumped after well flushing and approximately 45 ± 0.5 L of water was filtered through 0.2-μm sterile cellulose nitrate membrane filters (Sartorius, Göttingen, Germany) to capture microbial organisms from each groundwater well. All filtered membranes were frozen at -80 °C for high-throughput sequencing. Groundwater samples for physicochemical analysis were collected in 5 L sterile PET bottles and stored at -20 °C.

sec.title: Chemical Analysis
sec.p: Major anions (Cl−, NO3−, and SO42−) were measured using ion chromatography (Dionex ICS-600, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Massachusetts, USA), while major cations (Na+, K+, Mg2+, and Ca2+) were determined using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, Optima 8300, PerkinElmer, Massachusetts, USA). Trace elements, including U, Fe, and other transition metals, were quantified using inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS, 7900 ICP-MS, Agilent Technologies, California, USA). Alkalinity was measured by Gran titration using a Metrohm 888 Titrando (Metrohm, Herisau, Switzerland). The total organic carbon (TOC) and dissolved organic carbon (DOC) concentrations were determined using a TOC analyzer (TOC-L, Shimadzu, Kyoto, Japan). The gross alpha and gross beta radioactivity of groundwater samples were measured using a low-background α/β meter (LB6008, Beijing Yida Measurement Technology Co., Ltd., Beijing, China) following the thick source method for radioactivity analysis. Measurements of gross alpha and gross beta radioactivity were conducted at the China Nuclear Mining Science and Technology Corporation, Beijing, China, to assess radiological characteristics associated with uranium mobilization.

sec.title: DNA extraction and sequencing
sec.p: Total metagenomic DNA was extracted from biomass retained on 0.22-μm sterile cellulose nitrate membrane from 60 groundwater samples, selected from a total of 80 samples retrieved from different neutral-pH ISL stages in ore-bearing aquifers (see above and Figure 1). DNA extraction was performed using the FastDNA® SPIN Kit for Soil (MP Biomedicals, Solon, OH, USA) following the manufacturer’s protocol. The concentration and purity of the DNA extracts were measured using a TBS-380 fluorometer (Turner Biosystem, USA) and a NanoDrop 2000 spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific, USA), respectively. The quality of the DNA extracts was checked using 1%-agarose gel electrophoresis. Paired-end sequencing was performed on the Illumina HiSeq XTen platform (Illumina, Inc., San Diego, CA, USA) at Majorbio Bio-Pharm Technology Co., Ltd., China. DNA extracts were fragmented to an average size of approximately 400 bp using a Covaris M220 ultrasonicator (Gene Company Limited, China). Paired-end libraries were constructed using the NEXTFLEX Rapid DNA-Seq Kit (Bioo Scientific, Austin, TX, USA), with adapters containing the full complement of sequencing primer hybridization sites ligated to the blunt end of fragments.

sec.title: Metagenome processing and MAG recovery
sec.p: Raw reads were trimmed and quality-filtered using fastp v0.19.781. The microbial diversity and its coverage based on quality-filtered raw metagenomic reads was estimated by Nonpareil v3.4.125 in “kmer” mode. High-quality reads from individual samples were assembled into scaffolds using metaSPAdes version 3.15.5 (--k-list 21, 33, 55, 77, 99, and 127)82. Open-Reading Frames on scaffolds were predicted using prodigal (v2.6.3)83 in “meta” mode. MAGs were recovered from each assembly using the binning module (parameters: -metabat2 -maxbin2 -concoct) within metaWRAP v1.3 (metabat2 v2.12.1, MaxBin2 v.2.2.6, and concoct v0.4.0)84–87, which bins based on reads mapped only from the corresponding sample. Quality of genome bins (completeness and contamination) was evaluated using CheckM2 (v2.0.11)88. The best MAG representative for each sample was determined using DASTool v1.1.7 with default parameters89. Finally, a total of 4036 MAGs were obtained with completeness >50% and contamination <10%. Bins were further consolidated via dereplication at strain level using dRep (v.3.2.2) at 99% ANI90 resulting in 2,255 strain-cluster representative MAGs (strain-cluster rMAGs).

sec.title: Taxonomic classification of strain-cluster rMAGs and phylogenetic tree generation
sec.p: Taxonomies were assigned to each strain-cluster rMAG using GTDB-Tk v2.1.1 (https://github.com/Ecogenomics/GtdbTk, database release 220)91. Conserved marker genes (ribosomal proteins and RNA polymerase subunits) were identified using MarkerFinder (-m ribo_rnap, -c) (https://github.com/faylward/markerfinder) and concatenated into a supermatrix, which were used for constructing a maximum-likelihood phylogenetic tree via IQ-TREE 2 (v 2.2.0.3)92 with 1,000 ultrafast bootstrapping iterations. ModelFinder93 determined Qpfam+I+I+R10 to be the best model. The phylogenetic tree was visualized using the Interactive Tree of Life (iTOL)94.

sec.title: Coverage estimation and metabolic potential prediction
sec.p: Clean reads from each sample were mapped to strain-cluster rMAGs using strobealign (v0.13.0)95 in CoverM (v0.7.0; default parameters)96. The metabolic potential of strain-cluster rMAGs was determined using METABOLIC v4.097. We constructed two databases, one containing 96 genes associated with DNA repair mechanisms and one containing 32 genes implicated in microbial responses to oxidative stress, with all genes being sourced from NCBI (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/). Genes of strain-cluster rMAGs were annotated against these databases using DIAMOND BLAST98 with an E-value threshold of 1e-5 and the parameter -k 1 to retain only the top scoring hit. To ensure the specificity of these annotations, a reverse BLAST was subsequently conducted by aligning database hits back against the original amino acid sequences of the corresponding strain-cluster rMAGs using the same E-value threshold. Only reciprocal hits that aligned to the same ORFs as the original query were retained, ensuring one-to-one correspondence. Cases with multiple high-scoring matches were excluded to avoid ambiguous annotations. Final hits were filtered based on a similarity threshold of >50%, ensuring high-confidence functional assignments. These curated datasets facilitated a refined analysis of microbial resilience and adaptation strategies in diverse environmental contexts.

sec.title: Community profiling based on the rpS3 marker gene
sec.p: ORFs representing the rpS3 marker gene were identified using hmmsearch99 against custom Hidden Markov Models (HMMs) for Archaea and Bacteria (E-value 1e-28; https://github.com/AJProbst/rpS3_trckr). Sequences were pooled and clustered at 99% similarity using vsearch100, representing species-level clusters101. Representative sequences were selected following a tiered approach: (1) centroids that could be extended by 1000 bp in both directions, (2) non-centroids that were similarly extendable, and (3) the longest available sequence when neither of the first two criteria were met. To improve abundance estimates, rpS3 gene sequences of representative rpS3 genes were extended by up to 1,000 bp in both directions on their scaffold of origin if possible. This was done as mapping on just the approximately 1,000 bp long rpS3 gene results in poor mapping on the gene edges and this has progressively more impact when the total length of the sequence is short. The resulting rpS3 gene sequences, ideally extended in both directions by 1,000 bp, are henceforth called rpS3-extended. The workflow for clustering, extracting, and calculating coverage is available at https://github.com/ProbstLab/publication-associated_scripts/tree/main/FigueroaGonzalez_Bornemann_etal. The rpS3 genes in rpS3-extended sequences (in amino acid format) were taxonomically classified using DIAMOND98 (E-value ≤ 1e−5) against the GTDB r220 protein database, assigning the best hit to be the taxonomy. If no hit meeting the search criteria was found, “Unclassified” was assigned. Abundance was calculated by mapping reads of all metagenomic samples to rpS3-extended sequences and calculating the average coverage per sample. Additionally, the breadth, i.e., the number of nucleotide positions in rpS3-extended having a coverage of at least 1, was determined. The coverage of an rpS3-extended sequence in a given sample was set to zero if the breadth of the sequence in that sample was less than 95%, indicating spurious mapping instead of actual presence of the rpS3-extended-represented species. Relative coverage values were transformed into percentages (%).

sec.title: RNA extraction, sequencing, and metatranscriptomics
sec.p: Total RNA was isolated and purified using Soil RNA Extraction Kit (Majorbio, Shanghai, China) following the manufacturer's procedure. The integrity and quantity of the extracted RNA were measured with a NanoDrop 2000 spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific, MA, USA) and an Agilent 5300 Bioanalyzer (Agilent Technologies, Palo Alto, CA, USA). The RNA was subjected to standard Illumina library preparation with an Illumina® Stranded mRNA Prep, Ligation (Illumina, San Diego, CA, USA), and rRNA was depleted using a RiboCop rRNA Depletion Kit for Mixed Bacterial Samples (Lexogen, USA). Depleted RNA was extracted from biomass retained on 0.22 μm sterile cellulose nitrate membranes from 60 groundwater samples (same to metagenomic groundwater samples) and finally library preparation of RNA extraction from 45 groundwater samples were successfully constructed (Figure 1). Sequencing was performed on an Illumina Novaseq6000 sequencer (Illumina, San Diego, CA, USA) with paired-end sequencing method at Majorbio Bio-Pharm Technology Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Quality control of the raw data generated by sequencing was carried out with fastp v0.19.781. SortMeRNA (v4.3.6) was used to remove non-coding RNA sequences (tRNA, tmRNA, 5S, 16S, 18S, 23S, and 28S)102. The proportion of reads removed per sample is summarized in Supplementary Table S3 and Figure S17, providing an overview of rRNA/tRNA content prior to filtering.

sec.title: Gene overexpression in each metatranscriptome
sec.p: InStrain (v1.8.1)103 with the parameter (--min_cov 0) was used on strain-cluster rMAGs recovered from the same sample to get the coverage of each gene using the clean reads from each metagenome and each metatranscriptome. The gene coverage in each strain-cluster rMAG was received by using the cluster database generated when dereplicate genomes at 99% ANI using dRep (v3.2.2)90. The mean coverage of 30S ribosomal proteins were used to calculate the normalization factor of each gene from the strain-cluster rMAGs in each metatranscriptome sample. The genes with normalization factor greater than two were defined as overexpressed genes.

sec.title: Species-level clustering and calculation of evolutionary metrics
sec.p: Filtered reads from each metagenome and metatranscriptome were mapped to the best MAGs output from DAStool of the same sample using strobealign (v0.13.0)95 in CoverM (v0.7.0; default parameters)96. Genetic annotation of MAGs was performed with Prodigal (v2.6.3; –p meta)83 for the gene module of inStrain (v1.8.1)103. Population statistics and nucleotide metrics, including nucleotide diversity (SNVs/kbp) and nonsynonymous to synonymous mutation ratios (pN/pS) were calculated from these mappings using the profile module of the inStrain program (v1.8.1; –database mode; default parameters)103 at genome and gene levels. The 4036 MAGs reconstructed from all individual assemblies (n = 60) were combined and dereplicated for species-level clustering using dRep (v3.2.2)90 at 95% ANI. A total of 1733 MAGs with the highest genome quality from each species cluster were designated as the representative species (species-cluster rMAGs). The species-cluster rMAGs with over three members in the cluster database generated when dereplicate genomes at 95% ANI were selected for the final calculation of microdiversity metrics such as coverage, breadth, SNPs density, nucleotide diversity, and pN/pS ratios.

For SNP calling, the number of quality-filtered reads mapping to the position had to be at least 5× coverage and 5% SNP frequency, and the variant based on reads had to be lower than the expected sequencing error rate (1e−6). Genome-level evolutionary metrics based on both metagenomic and metatranscriptomic data from mining sites were compared with those from background aquifer samples at the same location (Table S4, S5). To evaluate the impact of radioactivity and chemical stress on microbial genomes, 41 species rMAGs present in at least two groups (BG, MT, and PM) and in a minimum of three samples from each group were selected. Gene annotations for these 41 species rMAGs were performed (Table S6) using MetaCerberus v1.3.1104. Gene-level nucleotide diversity of microbial genes within these 41 rMAGs was then analyzed using both metagenomic and metatranscriptomic data across the BG, MT, and PM groups (Table S7,S8).

sec.title: Statistical analyses and data visualization
sec.p: Spearman correlation analyses were performed in the R platform (http://cran.r-project.org), with p-values adjusted using the Benjamini-Hochberg procedure at a minimum significance threshold of 0.05105. Co-occurrence networks were constructed using the igraph package with default parameters106. Only Spearman correlations with p-values < 0.001 and |ρ|> 0.6 between pairs of rMAGs were considered statistically significant, contributing to the construction of a reliable network. The resulting correlation network was imported into Gephi (v0.9.2) for visualization107. The Spearman correlations between over-expressed genes from rMAGs and hydrogeochemical variables were visualized using the pheatmap package in R (v4.4.2)108. To assess sample similarity and identify key factors driving clustering patterns, Principal Coordinates Analysis (PCoA) was conducted based on the Bray-Curtis dissimilarity of microbial community compositions. Analysis of Similarity (ANOSIM) was employed to evaluate significant differences among sample groups.
